entry.content:
This project focused the market structure using two-sample tests for high dimensional means and covariance and proposed approaches for tackling the instability of optimization solutions to improve the Markowitz model.

The following part was finished by me and Mingzhen Yang, Peking University.

Motivations

The mean-variance optimization (MVO) framework developed by Markowitz (1952) is certainly the most famous model used in asset management. However, according to our previous study, the distribution of the stock market is time-varying. Thus, if the sample size is too large, it is inaccurate to implement the model on the historical dataset for so long time. But if we use the recent data, the rolling window is too short, and the covariance matrix is singular. This is our motivation to research new methods to enhance the performance of the asset allocation strategy.

Markowitz Model

In the Markowitz model, optimized portfolios depend on expected returns and risks. The optimal portfolio is the solution to maximizing the investors' quadratic utility. Markowitz defined the quadratic utility function U\mathcal{U}U of the investor which only depends of the expected returns μ\muμ and the covariance matrix Σ\SigmaΣ of the assets:

\begin{equation} \mathcal{U}\left(x\right) =x(\mu-r 1)-\frac{\phi}{2} x^{\top} \Sigma x \end{equation}

The investor can select from nnn risky assets with a vector of weights x=(x1,⋯ ,xn)x = (x_1, \cdots , x_n)x=(x1​,⋯,xn​) where xix_ixi​ is the percentage of the wealth invested in the iii th asset. Let μ\muμ and Σ\SigmaΣ be the vector of expected returns and the covariance matrix of asset returns, rrr is the risk-free asset return and ϕ\phiϕ is the risk tolerance of the investor.

Evidently, maximizing the mean variance utility function is then equivalent to maximizing the Sharpe ratio of the allocation.

Estimators of MVO

Let Rt=(R1,t,⋯ ,Rn,t)R_t = (R_{1,t}, \cdots , R_{n,t})Rt​=(R1,t​,⋯,Rn,t​) be the vector of historical returns for the different assets at time ttt. We can estimate μ\muμ and Σ\SigmaΣ by maximum likelihood method:

\begin{equation} \begin{aligned} \hat{\mu} &=\frac{1}{T} \sum_{t=1}^{T} R_{t} \\ \hat{\Sigma} &=\frac{1}{T} \sum_{t=1}^{T}\left(R_{t}-\hat{\mu}\right)\left(R_{t}-\hat{\mu}\right)^{\top} \end{aligned} \end{equation}

However, if $p\rightarrow \infty ,,,\hat\Sigma$ can behave
very badly, unless it is “regularized” in some fashion. Moreover, if the matrix is ill-conditioned, the estimation errors can then dramatically change the weights leading to high turnover and high transaction costs. That is our motivation to develop techniques to enhance the performance under mean-variance framework.

Precision Matrix Estimation

As we can see, the performance of the portfolio optimization is clearly associated with the estimation accuracy of precision matrix. To overcome the obstacles, we consider two methods to high-dimensional inverse covariance matrix estimation: estimating a banded version of the inverse of the covariance, proposed by Bickel and Levina (2008), and the constrained ℓ1\ell_1ℓ1​ minimization approach proposed by Caiet al. (2011).

Banding Estimator

Suppose we have X=(X1,...,Xp)TX = (X_1,...,X_p)^TX=(X1​,...,Xp​)T defined on a probability space, with probability measure PPP , which is Np∼(0,Σp)N_p\sim (0,\Sigma_p)Np​∼(0,Σp​),Σp=[σij]\Sigma_p = [\sigma_{ij} ]Σp​=[σij​].

Let

\begin{equation} \hat{X}_{j}=\sum_{t=1}^{j-1} a_{j t} X_{t}=\mathbf{Z}_{j}^{T} \mathbf{a}_{j} \end{equation}

be the L2(P)L_2(P)L2​(P) projection of XjX_jXj​ on the linear span of X1,⋯ ,Xj−1X_1,\cdots,X_{j-1}X1​,⋯,Xj−1​, with Zj=(X1,⋯ ,Xj−1)T\mathbf Z_j = (X_1,\cdots,X_{j-1})^TZj​=(X1​,⋯,Xj−1​)T the vector of coordinates up to j−1j - 1j−1, and aj=(aj1,⋯ ,aj,j−1)T\mathbf a_j = (a_{j1},\cdots,a_{j,j-1})^Taj​=(aj1​,⋯,aj,j−1​)T the coefficients. If j=1j = 1j=1, let X^1=0\hat X_ 1 = 0X^1​=0.

When k<pk<pk<p, we restrict the variables in the previous regression to Zj(k)=(Xmax(j−k,1),⋯ ,Xj−1)\mathbf Z^{(k)}_j = (X_{max(j - k,1)},\cdots,X_{j-1})Zj(k)​=(Xmax(j−k,1)​,⋯,Xj−1​), that is, regressing each XjX_jXj​ on its closest kkk predecessors only. By replacing Zj\mathbf Z_jZj​ by Zj(k)\mathbf Z^{(k)}_jZj(k)​, we get new aj(k)\mathbf a^{(k)}_jaj(k)​.

aj(k)\mathbf a^{(k)}_jaj(k)​ can be computed as

\begin{equation} \mathbf{a}^{(k)}_{j}=\left(\operatorname{Var}\left(\mathbf{Z}^{(k)}_{j}\right)\right)^{-1} \operatorname{Cov}\left(X_{j}, \mathbf{Z}^{(k)}_{j}\right) \end{equation}

Let AkA_kAk​ be the kkk-banded lower triangular matrix with zeros on the diagonal contain the coefficients aj(k)a_j^{(k)}aj(k)​ arranged in rows. Let εj=Xj−X^j,dj2=Var⁡(εj)\varepsilon_{j}=X_{j}-\hat{X}_{j}, d_{j}^{2}=\operatorname{Var}\left(\varepsilon_{j}\right)εj​=Xj​−X^j​,dj2​=Var(εj​) and let Dk=diag(dj,k2)D_k = diag(d_{j,k}^2)Dk​=diag(dj,k2​) be the diagonal matrix containing the corresponding residual variances.

By applying the covariance operator to the identity ε=(I−A)X\varepsilon = (I - A)Xε=(I−A)X, we get the modified Cholesky decompositions of Σk,p−1\Sigma^{-1}_{k,p}Σk,p−1​:

\begin{equation} \Sigma_{k,p}^{-1}=(I-A_k)^{T} D_k^{-1}(I-A_k) \end{equation}

CLIME

Banding estimator work well when estimating fairly well-conditioned covariance matrices, while sometimes the covariance matrix of the portfolio can be ill-conditioned. Thus, we also apply the Constrained ℓ1\ell_1ℓ1​-Minimization for Inverse Matrix Estimation (CLIME) estimator to enhance the accuracy.

The CLIME estimator is defined by Cai, Liu and Zhou. First let {Ω^1}\{\hat\Omega_1\}{Ω^1​} be the solution set of the following optimization problem:

\begin{equation} \min \|\boldsymbol\Omega\|_{1} \text { subject to: }\left|\boldsymbol\Sigma_{n} \boldsymbol\Omega-\boldsymbol I\right|_{\infty} \leq \lambda_{n}, \quad \boldsymbol\Omega \in \mathbb{R}^{p \times p} \end{equation}

where λn\lambda_nλn​ is a tuning parameter, the matrix ℓ1\ell_1ℓ1​ norm ∥A∥1=∑i=1p∑j=1q∣ai,j∣\|A\|_{1}=\sum_{i=1}^{p} \sum_{j=1}^{q}\left|a_{i, j}\right|∥A∥1​=∑i=1p​∑j=1q​∣ai,j​∣, and the elementwise ℓ∞\ell_{\infty}ℓ∞​ norm ∣A∣∞=max⁡1≤i≤p,1≤j≤q∣aij∣|\boldsymbol{A}|_{\infty}=\max _{1 \leq i \leq p, 1 \leq j \leq q}\left|a_{i j}\right|∣A∣∞​=max1≤i≤p,1≤j≤q​∣aij​∣.

The solution is not symmetric in general. The final CLIME estimator of Ω0\boldsymbol\Omega_0Ω0​ is obtained by symmetrizing \boldsymbol\hat\Omega_1 as follows.

Write \boldsymbol\hat\Omega_1=(\omega_{ij}^1)=\left(\hat{\boldsymbol{\omega}}_{1}^{1}, \ldots, \hat{\boldsymbol{\omega}}_{p}^{1}\right), the CLIME estimator is defined as

\begin{equation} \hat{\boldsymbol\Omega}=\left(\hat{\omega}_{i j}\right), \text { where } \hat{\omega}_{i j}=\hat{\omega}_{j i}^{1} I\left\{\left|\hat{\omega}_{i j}^{1}\right| \leq\left|\hat{\omega}_{j i}^{1}\right|\right\}+\hat{\omega}_{j i}^{1} I\left\{\left|\hat{\omega}_{i j}^{1}\right|>\left|\hat{\omega}_{j i}^{1}\right|\right\} \end{equation}

Constrained ℓ1\ell_1ℓ1​ minimization provides an effective way for reconstructing a sparse signal.

Regression Methods

As is discussed above,the solution to maximizing the investor's utility without any constraints under the hypotheses of Mean-Variance model yields the formula:

\begin{equation*} x^{\star}=\frac{1}{\phi} \Sigma^{-1}(\mu-r \mathbf{1})=\gamma \Sigma^{-1}(\mu-r \mathbf{1}) \end{equation*}

Without lack of generality, we assume that the risk-free rate is equal to zero in the calculation of Sharpe ratio. If the investors' risk tolerance equals to one, then the solution is equivalent to coefficients solution of an ordinary least squares (OLS) problem that regress excess asset returns on a constant n×1n\times 1n×1 vector.

Thus this section is trying to resolve the invertible covariance matrix problem within the regression framework. To make it clear, when we try to figure out the optimized asset allocation based on mean-variance model under the circumstance that time length of estimation window is less than the number of assets, we can first apply the appropriate regression methods to regularizing the sample covariance matrix or reducing the dimension of independent variables to get the estimation of coefficients, and then by scaling the coefficients of regression, we obscure the allocated weight of each asset.

Lasso Regression

The motivation for the Lasso regression is to solve the non-singular problem of OLS coefficients estimation by adding L1L_1L1​-norm penalty term to the residual sum of squares, which is consistent with the regularization of the covariance matrix.

Below is a simple simulation study to explore the effect on the estimation of coefficients imposed by different selections of penalty term coefficients λ\lambdaλ. From the angle of the asset allocation problem, the constraint of the sum of the absolute values of weights improves the sparsity and thus the selection of assets in a large portfolio. Furthermore, by imposing a size on the weights, Lasso regression is also beneficial to stabilize the weight and reduce the turnover rate as well as the transaction cost of the investment strategy.

Ridge Regression

Ridge regression offers a different way of shrinking the asset position by specifying the penalty term as L2L_2L2​-norm of coefficients, which is smooth with closed-form solutions for the weights. Imposing the L2L_2L2​-norm constraint is equivalent to adding the same amount λ\lambdaλ to the diagonal elements of the covariance matrix. The shrinkage nature of Ridge regression is illustrated below.

Principal Component Regression

Principal Component regression (PCR) offers a different approach to solve the non-singular problem by directly reducing the data dimension. The idea of PCR is not to base the portfolio weights on the full set of assets, but only the variation in these assets that can be attributed to the underlying factors, which is sensible since most of the market common risk originates from several factors, e.g. macroeconomic fundamentals, investors' sentiment or industry-specific factors.

In the following empirical study, we first apply PCA to stock return data, then use cross validation method to select the best number of principal components and then regress the constant vector to selected principal components to get the estimation of asset weights. PCR regression coefficients corresponding to different selections of the number of principal components is presented below.

entry.content:
This project focused the market structure using two-sample tests for high dimensional means and covariance and proposed approaches for tackling the instability of optimization solutions to improve the Markowitz model.

The following part was finished by Mingzhen Yang, Peking University.

Introduction

In this paper, we propose approaches for tackling the instability of optimization solutions to improve the Markowitz model. We study the market structure using two-sample tests for high dimensional means and covariance, which motivates us to improve the basic framework for the mean-variance approach. Despite the simplicity of the mean-variance optimization, estimating the input parameters introduces the estimation errors, leading to the instability of portfolio weights. We present two estimation strategies for high-dimensional inverse covariance matrix estimation. Moreover, we propose penalization methods like Lasso and ridge regression from another perspective to regularize the inverse of the covariance matrix. In the end, we report the results of our empirical analysis conducted on a high dimensional dataset of stocks comprised in the CSI 300 index.

Exploratory Data Analysis

We study on a dataset made of the daily returns of the stocks comprised in CSI 300 Index between Jan 2010 and Nov 2019. After dropping the stocks with missing values, we select 176 stocks for high-dimensional sample tests. The dataset consists of p=176p=176p=176 stocks and n=2661n=2661n=2661 observations.

Two-Sample Tests for High Dimensional Means

We first conduct two-sample tests for multivariate means between any two years from 2010 to 2019. Since the result of the Shapiro-Wilk Test rejects the hypothesis of a normal distribution for every stock in our data set, we carry out Chen and Qin (2010) Test and visualize the ppp-value in the below figure.

Most of the time, the overall return levels of the Chinese stock market between two years in the recent decade are similar. Given significant level of 0.050.050.05, we have 6 pairs which show different returns between two years:(2011,2014),(2011,2017),(2011,2019),(2013,2014),(2014,2018),(2017,2018)(2011,2014), (2011,2017), (2011,2019), (2013,2014), (2014,2018), (2017,2018)(2011,2014),(2011,2017),(2011,2019),(2013,2014),(2014,2018),(2017,2018) Actually, they are all the pair of a bull year and a bear year, which is consistent with our intuition.

We also conduct the adjusted Chen-Qin Test, which calculates the p-value of the test for testing equality of two-sample high-dimensional mean vectors proposed by Chen et al. (2014) based on permutation or parametric bootstrap resampling and speeds up the original test. The results are presented below.

Adjusted ttt Test for Each Dimension

We then do ttt-tests for each stock's return in each pair of years listed above. We use Bonferroni and Benjamini-Hochberg correction to adjust the ppp-value of tests.

As is shown, the ppp-value adjusted by Benjamini-Hochberg correction is more conservative and there are just a small number of stocks that have significantly different returns in 2011 and 2014. However, considering that stock return data is not strictly normally distributed, the efficacy of multiple ttt-tests should be carefully considered.

Two Sample Tests for High-dimensional Covariance Matrices

We now want to have a look at the dependent relationship between stocks in recent years. First, we could have an intuitive feeling of the changes in market correlation by comparing the heat maps of correlation matrices in different years. It is presented that market risk structure, as well as risk aggregation in the Chinese market, has varied in recent 10 years. The dependence among stock was relatively strong in the years 2015 and 2016. In 2017, we could see that the relationship of stocks was weak compared with others, and some of the stocks are negatively correlated with others. In fact, when the dependence among the stocks is strengthened, systematic risk is increasing too, which imposes a threat to the investors' investment portfolio which is built based on the risk calculation.

To further validate our findings, we carry out tests to test the equality of covariance matrices for the stock returns between any two years in the recent decade. We use the high dimensional covariance matrices equality test by Li and Chen (2012) using a linear combination of three one-sample U statistics and an unbiased estimator of the Frobenius norm of Σ1−Σ2\Sigma_{1}-\Sigma_{2}Σ1​−Σ2​, which is of good test power without the hypothesis of normal distribution. And we also try the test raised by Cai et al. (2013) using the maximum norm, which focuses on sparse alternatives.
